X-Powered-By: ASP.NET
Date: Sun, 14 Apr 2019 01:46:31 GMT

CVE-2017-7269.summary: Buffer overflow in the ScStoragePathFromUrl function in the WebDAV service in Internet Information Services (IIS) 6.0 in Microsoft Windows Server 2003 R2 allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via a long header beginning with "If: <http://" in a PROPFIND request, as exploited in the wild in July or August 2016.

CVE-2009-2521.summary: Stack consumption vulnerability in the FTP Service in Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 5.0 through 7.0 allows remote authenticated users to cause a denial of service (daemon crash) via a list (ls) -R command containing a wildcard that references a subdirectory, followed by a .. (dot dot), aka "IIS FTP Service DoS Vulnerability."

CVE-2003-1582.summary: Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 6.0, when DNS resolution is enabled for client IP addresses, allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary text into log files via an HTTP request in conjunction with a crafted DNS response, as demonstrated by injecting XSS sequences, related to an "Inverse Lookup Log Corruption (ILLC)" issue.

CVE-2010-1899.summary: Stack consumption vulnerability in the ASP implementation in Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 5.1, 6.0, 7.0, and 7.5 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (daemon outage) via a crafted request, related to asp.dll, aka "IIS Repeated Parameter Request Denial of Service Vulnerability."

CVE-2009-1535.summary: The WebDAV extension in Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 5.1 and 6.0 allows remote attackers to bypass URI-based protection mechanisms, and list folders or read, create, or modify files, via a %c0%af (Unicode / character) at an arbitrary position in the URI, as demonstrated by inserting %c0%af into a "/protected/" initial pathname component to bypass the password protection on the protected\ folder, aka "IIS 5.1 and 6.0 WebDAV Authentication Bypass Vulnerability," a different vulnerability than CVE-2009-1122.

CVE-2009-4444.summary: Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 5.x and 6.x uses only the portion of a filename before a ; (semicolon) character to determine the file extension, which allows remote attackers to bypass intended extension restrictions of third-party upload applications via a filename with a (1) .asp, (2) .cer, or (3) .asa first extension, followed by a semicolon and a safe extension, as demonstrated by the use of asp.dll to handle a .asp;.jpg file.

CVE-2008-1446.summary: Integer overflow in the Internet Printing Protocol (IPP) ISAPI extension in Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 5.0 through 7.0 on Windows 2000 SP4, XP SP2 and SP3, Server 2003 SP1 and SP2, and Server 2008 allows remote authenticated users to execute arbitrary code via an HTTP POST request that triggers an outbound IPP connection from a web server to a machine operated by the attacker, aka "Integer Overflow in IPP Service Vulnerability."

CVE-2007-1278.summary: Unspecified vulnerability in the IIS connector in Adobe JRun 4.0 Updater 6, and ColdFusion MX 6.1 and 7.0 Enterprise, when using Microsoft IIS 6, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service via unspecified vectors, involving the request of a file in the JRun web root.

CVE-2010-1256.summary: Unspecified vulnerability in Microsoft IIS 6.0, 7.0, and 7.5, when Extended Protection for Authentication is enabled, allows remote authenticated users to execute arbitrary code via unknown vectors related to "token checking" that trigger memory corruption, aka "IIS Authentication Memory Corruption Vulnerability."

CVE-2009-3023.summary: Buffer overflow in the FTP Service in Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 5.0 through 6.0 allows remote authenticated users to execute arbitrary code via a crafted NLST (NAME LIST) command that uses wildcards, leading to memory corruption, aka "IIS FTP Service RCE and DoS Vulnerability."

http.html:
What's New!

Community Meeting on December 4, 2013, to Discuss the Future Long-Range Vision for Dell Avenue

Interested parties are encouraged to participate in this community meeting to be held on Wednesday, December 4, 2013, at 6:30 p.m. This meeting will be held in the Orchard City Banquet Hall at the Campbell Community Center. Questions can be directed to Paul Kermoyan at (408) 866-2140 or via email to

Additional information

Online Pet Licensing Now Available

The Silicon Valley Animal Control Authority has launched their web licensing service, where owners are now able to license their dogs and cats. Please visit www.svaca.com for further information.

City Council and Planning Commission Webcasts Now Available on Apple Devices

The City has recently upgraded its webcasting software. Now, the public can watch City Council and Planning Commission webcasts on portable devices, such as iPads and Android-based tablets. For more information, please call (408) 866-2128.

What Kind of Place Will Santa Clara Valley Be in 2043? What Will the Quality of Life Be For Our Children and Grandchildren?

The Santa Clara County Open Space Authority seeks input into the 30 Year Conservation Vision-- Join the community forum at www.CVW3.org

For over 20 years, the Open Space Authority has been partnering with communities to protect our waters, wildlife, and working lands in the Valley for the benefit of current and future generations. The Authority’s efforts to protect the health of our land and natural resources helps keep our drinking water supplies clean and safe, our wildlife and habitat healthy and the agricultural sector strong and thriving. The Open Space Authority also improves the livability of our cities through its Urban Open Space Grants Program and has contributed over $8 million to local community projects such as clean creeks, walking and biking trails, and community parks.

The Open Space Authority is now creating a 30-Year Conservation Vision to identify strategic partnerships and priorities for investments in local and regional open space projects (including greenbelts, creeks & waterways, trails, urban-edge farms, and habitat restoration). The Authority wants to know what you like best about living in the Valley:

• Access to nearby trails for hiking, biking and equestrian use?
• Clean creeks?
• Community gardens?
• Protection of local farms and ranches that provide fresh, nutritious fruits and vegetables?
• Protection of wildlife habitat?
• Protection of scenic hillsides?
• Science-based environmental education programs for kids?

In order to help ensure healthy, livable communities for all, please contribute your ideas for the Open Space Authority’s 30- year Conservation Vision: Water, Wildlife and Working Lands by August 30th at www.CVW3.org.

The Open Space Authority thanks you – and future generations will thank you, too!

To sign up for regular updates from the Open Space Authority, copy-paste this URL into your browser: http://openspaceauthority.wufoo.com/forms/z7x4m1/.

Visit www.openspaceauthority.org to learn more.

Translation
Advisory Commission Openings:

The City Clerk’s Office is accepting applications for vacancies on the following Boards and Commissions:

Rental Increase Fact Findig Committee – The Chairperson term expired August 31, 2011 and remains unfilled. A tenant position is also vacant. The Committee is composed of five members selected by the City Council to assist in resolving disputes which are presented to the City by petition. The Committee is composed of two tenant representatives, two landlord representatives, and one neutral representative who shall act as Chairperson. A tenant member shall not participate in a proceeding involving a landlord from whom he or she rents residential property. Members shall serve without monetary remuneration. Tenant applicants must be a tenant and live within the Campbell City limits. Landlord applicants must own rental property in the City of Campbell. Meetings are held as needed.

Application forms are available below, and on the City Clerk/Boards and Commission page, or by calling the City Clerk's Office at (408) 866-2117.

- Advisory Boards and Commissions Application (32kb pdf)

Mayor's State of the City Address - May 22, 2013

Heritage Theatre
One W. Campbell Ave.
Campbell, CA 95008

Mayor Evan Low presented an update on City projects and programs and call to action for community building on May 22nd. This very well attended community event was telecast live on cable channel 26 and on the City's website at www.CityofCampbell.com. If you were unable to attend, you can watch the archived video of the event.

- Watch Archived Video

For any questions, please call (408) 866-2128.
Campbell Welcomes Annexation Area Residents Into City Limits

The City Council for the City of Campbell extends its warmest welcome to the City's newest residents. Following several year's worth of effort on the part of a neighborhood working in partnership with representatives from the cities of Campbell and San Jose, the residents of a County Pocket (Cambrian 36) and a former San Jose area (Central Park Drive neighborhood) reached their goal and are now officially a part of Campbell. This annexation is effective as of May 1, 2013. Campbell is pleased to have extended its boundaries to include this area. The link below offers some general information for the City's newest residents. Welcome to Campbell!

Welcome Packet for Annexation Area Residents - 2013 (Digital Edition)
Welcome Packet for Annexation Area Residents - 2013 (pdf)

Single-Use Carryout Bags Restriction (Updated June 25, 2013)
On June 18, following a series of informational meetings with local businesses and residents, the City Council introduced an ordinance regulating the distribution of single-use, carryout bags and requiring a charge for paper bags. The new ordinance, scheduled for second reading on July 16, would become effective on January 27, 2014.

  • Regulates single-use, carryout bags at all retail businesses selling clothing, food, and personal items directly to consumers.
  • Exempts restaurants, fast-food places, and nonprofit charitable reuse organizations, such as Goodwill.
  • Bans single-use, carryout bags.
  • Allows recycled-content paper carryout bags or reusable carryout bags for a minimum charge of 10 cents per bag (increases to 25 cents January 1, 2015).
  • Reusable carryout bag means either a bag made of cloth or other machine-washable fabric that has handles, or a durable bag with handles that is at least 2.25 millimeters thick and is specifically designed and manufactured for multiple reuse.
  • Exempts gift bags.
  • Exempts customers enrolled in the State's supplemental food stamps programs.
  • Allows retailers to provide protective bags for produce, meat, prescriptions, live fish, greeting cards, or garment bags (dry cleaning, clothing) at no charge.
  • Retailers keep the 10 cents from the sale of the bag.
  • Retailers must itemize the purchase of any recycled paper or reusable bag on sales receipt.
  • Retailers must keep records at the store for three years and make available upon request by the City.
  • The ordinance would be effective January 27, 2014.

City Staff will develop and begin an outreach program to local retailers to assist with implementation of the ordinance and advisory information to local residents.

Additional information can be found at:
- June 18 Council Report Item 16
- More information on actions to date

2013 Great American Litter Pickup

The City of Campbell held their annual Great American Litter Pickup Event, on Saturday, April 20, 2013, from 8:00 am to 12:00 pm, at the Los Gatos Creek County Park. The Great American Litter Pickup event is a national event wherein volunteers across our nation participate in a volunteer cleanup program.

Over 180 volunteers including students, neighborhood associations, church, service groups, seniors and families participated in the event. The weather was beautiful!

Volunteers removed debris from the on and off ramps of Highway 17 at Camden, the railroad tracks along Winchester from Hacienda northbound to Old Camden, the Los Gatos Creek County Park and trail, debris and graffiti removal was also performed from the Creekside overcrossing along the Los Gatos Creek.

A total of 2,180 pounds of debris and recyclables was collected.

Generous donations were provided by Campbell Home Depot, Kelly-Moore Paints, Subway (Bascom/Camden), Whole Foods, Starbucks and the Keep California Beautiful organization. The Campbell Rotary Clubs assisted with the cleanup..

Volunteers came from the City of Campbell and other surrounding cities from within the County of Santa Clara. Many of the volunteers had participated in previous City cleanup events.

Volunteers were satisfied and proud of their community service and had a good time!

- Photo Album
- Event Flyer
- Event Statistics
- Event Sponsors
- Campbell Reporter Facebook Post on Event

Campbell Promotional Videos
The City of Campbell worked with CGI Communications to create a set of promotional videos for the City of Campbell. The video clips highlight Campbell’s neighborhoods, businesses, amenities, and way of life.

To watch sample video clips from other communities, go to the Mayor's TV website.

American Lung Association Releases 2013 Tobacco Report Card
Campbell Receives Best Overall Grade Among Cities in County. On Wednesday, January 16, the American Lung Association (ALA) released its 11th annual State of Tobacco Control Report for all cities and towns in California.

Although 13 out of 15 incorporated municipalities in Santa Clara County received an overall grade of ‘D’ or ‘F’, Campbell staff is pleased to learn that the City received an overall tobacco control grade of ‘B’. The only jurisdiction receiving a higher grade than Campbell was the County.

The two main reasons why Campbell ranked so high is because of the City’s outdoor smoking policy and tobacco retail licensing ordinance which was just adopted last November. For the policy categories on Smokefree Outdoor Air and on Reducing Sales of Tobacco Products, the ALA awarded Campbell with ‘A’ grades in each. Except for San Jose which received a “B’, no other city or town in Santa Clara County came close.
Strong Cities | Strong State Campaign
The League of California Cities announced that Campbell is the newest city to be highlighted as part of their Strong Cities | Strong State campaign. Campbell’s pages are now live and can be accessed by the following link: www.strongcitiesstrongstate.com/city/campbell.

Currently, 154 California cities are profiled on the Strong Cities | Strong State website. Of these, Campbell is the first West Valley City to be highlighted and joins five other Santa Clara County cities being profiled including the Cities of Gilroy, Morgan Hill, Mountain View, San Jose and Santa Clara.

Online Crime Reporting
The Campbell Police Department is excited to announce the launch of its new online crime reporting service. The Desk Officer Reporting System (DORS) by COPLOGIC allows citizens to submit police reports online 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

The Campbell Police Department prides itself on the service we provide to the community including sending officers to all types of calls for service. This online reporting system is not intended to replace personal contact by officers, but instead is envisioned as an additional tool for you to use to report crimes in the event that you do not wish personal contact by an officer.

- More information or file an online report
Did You Know?...
Campbell Has Charging Stations for Electric Cars
The City of Campbell joins other local municipalities in their efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by installing 10 electric charging stations.

ChargePoint® charging stations have been installed at the following public parking facilities: the Second Street Parking Garage located on Civic Center between Second and Third Street; the First Street Parking Garage adjacent to the Water Tower Office Plaza; the Campbell Community Center, Building H. and the City parking lot located at the corner of First Street and Civic Center Drive.

For the first six months of this new service, there will be no charge for the usage of the electric stations. After the trial period, the City will evaluate whether a cost should be applied for their usage.

For additional information on alternative fuel vehicles, data analysis, incentives and laws, clean air buying guides, rebates, carpool lane and sticker information, search maps, Chargepoint® and more, please visit the following websites:


US Department of Energy: Recent Publications, Data Analysis and Trends, Incentives and Laws, Vehicle Data Center which includes a basic station search, map a route and state search features.

California Environmental Protection Agency Clean Air Resources Board: Clean Air Buying Guide, Incentives (Fastrak toll requirements, rebates, car pool lane sticker information).

DriveClean California: California Air Resources Board: A Buyer’s Guide For Clean And Efficient Vehicles

Chargepoint: Locate additional Chargepoint® stations, download phone apps for Android, iPhone and Blackberry phones, ordering and activating Chargepoint® cards.

Join Your Campbell Neighborhood On Nextdoor.com
Nextdoor is a free and private social networking site for your neighborhood that builds community by connecting neighbors to one another.

- More Information (124kb pdf)

East Campbell Avenue Portals Project
The City Council approved the preliminary design for the East Campbell Avenue Portal Project during the September 4, 2012 Council Meeting. The project is currently in final design.

- East Campbell Avenue Portals Project Page

City Receives Award for Financial Reporting
The Government Finance Officers Association (GFOA) notified the City of Campbell that its Comprehensive Annual Financial Report has been awarded a Certificate of Achievement for Excellence in Financial Reporting, which is the highest form of recognition in government accounting and financial reporting. According to the GFOA, this attainment “represents a significant accomplishment by a government and its management.”

- Press Release (188kb pdf)

Campbell Recreation and Community Services is on Facebook!
If you are a Facebook user, be sure to “Like” our page to learn about upcoming events, gain access to special promotions and receive tips on how to live a fun, active and healthy lifestyle in Campbell. We hope you join the conversation on our Facebook page and please be sure to invite your friends!

- https://www.facebook.com/CampbellRecreation

Discover, Explore, and Learn at the Campbell Library
The Campbell Library has so much to offer - the latest bestsellers, movies, games, CDs, and audio books. Sign up for NextReads, and have reading suggestions emailed to you. Check the online calendar for information about book discussion groups, lectures, author appearances, classes, travel programs, children's programs, and more. Attend storytimes for infants to school-age children to help them develop their language, motor, and creative skills.

- More Information
CrimeReports
The Police Department is excited to announce that our crime data is now accessible on-line through CrimeReports.com. We recently partnered with CrimeReports, creators of the National Crime Map, to give members of the public access to a comprehensive map of crime in the community.

Working with nearly 800 law enforcement agencies across North America, including almost all of the agencies in Santa Clara County, CrimeReports is the largest and most accurate online resource for up-to-date crime information. CrimeReports offers community members free email crime alerts, sex offender information, and the most comprehensive public crime mapping service on the web.

The CrimeReports service is free to the public and is newly available as a free iPhone app, so citizens can be aware of crime around them while on the go. For more information about CrimeReports: www.CrimeReports.com.

- Campbell CrimeReports

New E-Services Page
The City of Campbell is continually looking to provide innovative services that increase accessibility to our community, while reducing costs and helping keep Campbell a “Green” city. E-services provide a secure and environment-friendly option for registering for classes, purchasing tickets, paying for some permits and staying current with what is taking place in our community.
The E-Services page gives you “one-click” access to our electronic services making it easier to do business with the City, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, without having to come to City Hall. We hope you find this new service helpful and convenient.
